section.title: Purpose and Description
section.paragraph: The coagulation and disinfection processes require the precise dosage of coagulant and calcium hypochlorite. To carry out these processes without pumps, the AguaClara plant uses a gravity dosing system.

section.title: Main components
section.paragraph: The main components of the system are:

list_item.paragraph: Two tanks to store the stock solution of each chemical (four in total).
A platform to raise the tanks.
Two constant load boats for each chemical (4 in total) that maintain a reservoir at a constant level using a float valve at the inlet.
A balance that connects the water level in the plant’s entrance tank with the level at the chemical system outlet.
A series of hoses in the path of the chemical from the constant charge canister to the balance, which provides the necessary relationship between the pressure drop and the flow rate of the chemical.
One flow measurement column for each chemical.

section.paragraph: The blue arrows indicate the path of the chemist. The height of the hose outlet on the slider controls the flow rate of the chemical.

figure.caption: Diagram of an AguaClara dispenser mounted on the wall of the entrance tank.

section.title: Semi-automatic system
section.paragraph: This system has the following characteristics:

list_item.paragraph: The flow of the chemical is automatically stopped when there is no water flow in the plant.

It changes the flow rate of the chemicals automatically in proportion to the water level in the entrance tank, which is proportional to the flow rate of the plant thanks to the linear flow meter (previous section).

section.paragraph: The first provides safety against overdose and chemical waste in the event that the flow of water in the plant is stopped without manually stopping the flow of chemical. The second allows an experienced operator to choose the chemical dosage easily, without making any calculations, and without having to manipulate the system every time the flow in the plant changes.
The system is not fully automatic because it requires an operator to choose the dose of each chemical and verify that that dose is being applied.

section.names: bote\ de\ carga\ constante constant\ load\ boat heading_bote_de_carga_constante
section.title: Constant Load Boat
section.paragraph: The constant load boat maintains a constant level of fluid that defines the starting height of the chemical’s journey. The level is maintained by a float valve at the bottle inlet. With the canister the height of the start of the chemical’s journey is independent of the amount of chemical stored.

section.title: The balance
section.paragraph: With the constant loading boat defining the height of the start of the run and the pipes and hoses carrying the chemical permanently installed, the flow of the chemical depends only on the height of the end of the run. This end of the system is connected to a balance mounted on the wall of the inlet tank. On the other side of the balance is connected a submerged float in the entrance tank which tilts the balance depending on the water level in the tank (Fig. 13), which depends on the water flow (Linear Flow Orifice Meter (LFOM)).

figure.caption: The balance is tilted depending on the water level in the entrance tank.

section.paragraph: The point where the hose that leads the chemical to the balance is mounted on the balance is a slider that can run along the balance. The dose of the chemical is chosen by manipulating the position of the slider, thus changing the height of the end of the run (Fig. 14).

figure.caption: The final height of the chemical run can change because 1) the water flow in the plant changes or 2) the position of the slider is manipulated to change the dose.

section.paragraph: When there is no water flow in the plant the scale is level, so that the final height of the run is equal to the water level in the constant load boat. In this situation the chemical does not flow. When the flow in the plant increases, the float causes the balance to tilt further, lowering the height of the hose and increasing the flow of the chemical in proportion to the flow in the plant.

To manipulate the coagulant dose, the operator changes the position of the slider on the scale. The lower this slider is placed on the inclined scale, the greater the flow rate of the chemical and the corresponding dose. In the highest possible position (marked as 0% in the numbering) the hose outlet is flush with the fluid in the constant load pot and the chemical does not flow regardless of the tilt of the balance. In the lowest possible position (marked as 100% in the numbering), the maximum dose (|C.CoagDoseMax| of coagulant or |C.ChlorDoseMax| of chlorine for this design) will be applied. Between these two extremes the relationship is linear, so that the percentage indicated by the number on the balance is the percentage of the maximum dose that is applied with the balance in that position.

When the slider is reached on the balance, the chemical falls freely through a tube of ½”, thus isolating the path to the balance hydraulically. To allow the scale to move freely, this tube is connected to another large diameter flexible hose under the plant floor. This hose is connected to the pipe that carries the chemical to the injection point.

section.names: mangueras\ de\ diámetro\ pequeño:\ elemento\ principal\ de\ pérdida\ de\ carga small\ diameter\ hoses:\ main\ element\ of\ pressure\ drop heading_small_hoses
section.title: Small diameter hoses: main element of pressure drop
section.paragraph: On the way from the constant load can to the balance, the chemical passes through a series of small diameter hoses in parallel. Almost all of the pressure drop along the path of the chemical occurs here. In this way, with the design of the hoses it is possible to control the relationship between the flow rate of the chemical and the height change of the path.

The flow through the straight hoses makes the higher pressure drop dominate, and the lower losses (of expansions) are kept to a minimum. This is important because the proportioner has a linear relationship between the height of the chemical’s end of its journey (connected to the water level in the entrance tank) and the chemical’s flow rate. Higher loss systems with laminar flow provide this linear relationship while lower losses have a non-linear relationship with the flow rate.
